importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of Sarkozy's arrival at prison marks a historic moment as the first former EU head of state to serve a jail sentence, raising global attention on accountability in political leadership.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeline of Sarkozy’s sentencing and incarceration highlights the immediate political and legal consequences of corruption charges against a former head of state.

keyTakeAways: Nicolas Sarkozy, former President of France, began serving a five-year jail sentence in Paris after being convicted of criminal conspiracy involving illegal campaign funding from Muammar Gaddafi.
Sarkozy is the first former head of a European Union country to be imprisoned, making the case a landmark in European political accountability.
The conviction stems from accepting millions of euros from Gaddafi to fund his 2007 presidential campaign, a claim he has consistently denied.
Sarkozy's lawyers filed a release request immediately after sentencing, with the court having two months to review it.
He will be held in solitary confinement in a nine-square-metre cell, with one daily walk and three weekly visits, due to security and legal concerns.
Presiding judge Nathalie Gavarino described the offenses as of 'exceptional gravity' and ruled that imprisonment is mandatory even with an appeal.
Sarkozy expressed belief in his innocence and stated he will take a Bible and the novel 'The Count of Monte Cristo' with him as symbolic gestures of justice and resilience.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Nicolas Sarkozy, former President of France, has begun a five-year jail term at La Santé Prison in Paris after being found guilty of criminal conspiracy for accepting millions of euros from Libyan ruler Muammar Gaddafi to fund his 2007 election campaign. This makes him the first former head of state in the European Union to be imprisoned, marking a significant moment in political accountability. Though Sarkozy has always denied the allegations, the judge, Nathalie Gavarino, described the crimes as of 'exceptional gravity' and ruled that imprisonment is mandatory even with an appeal. He will be held in solitary confinement with limited contact and will be allowed one daily walk and three weekly visits. His lawyers have filed a release request, which the court will review within two months. The case has sparked public outcry and emotional reactions from supporters, who view it as a blow to democracy and the rule of law.
title: Former French president Nicolas Sarkozy starts five-year jail term
